fullProgramDescription: The Linguistics major at UC San Diego is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental principles of language structure, language use, and language acquisition. The program covers various subfields of linguistics, including phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics, as well as the social and psychological aspects of language. Students are trained in the scientific study of language, including data collection, analysis, and theoretical modeling.
shortProgramDescription: The Linguistics B.A. program at UC San Diego provides a rigorous foundation in the scientific study of language, preparing students for careers in language teaching, speech pathology, or further study in linguistics or related fields.
classHighlights: The introductory course, LIGN100, provides an overview of the field of linguistics, covering the core subfields and introducing students to the scientific study of language. Subsequent courses in phonetics (LIGN120), phonology (LIGN121), morphology (LIGN122), and syntax (LIGN130) provide a comprehensive understanding of the sound and structure of language.

Courses in semantics (LIGN140) and pragmatics (LIGN150) examine the meaning and use of language, while sociolinguistics (LIGN160) and psycholinguistics (LIGN170) explore the social and psychological aspects of language. Students also have the opportunity to take courses in specialized areas, such as language acquisition (LIGN180) and linguistic theory (LIGN200).

Upper-division courses, such as LIGN165 (Language and Culture) and LIGN173 (Language Development), allow students to explore specific topics in linguistics in greater depth. Students are also required to take LIGN199 (Research Methods in Linguistics), which provides training in research design, data collection, and analysis.
learningOutcomes: Understand the fundamental principles of language structure, including phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics.
Analyze and describe the sound and structure of language using linguistic theories and models.
Apply linguistic theories to the study of language acquisition, language use, and language variation.
Demonstrate an understanding of the social and psychological aspects of language, including language and culture, language and identity, and language processing.
Design and conduct research projects in linguistics, including data collection, analysis, and interpretation.
creditRequirements: 180 quarter units, including52 upper-division units in Linguistics
additionalInformation: Students are advised to consult with the Linguistics department advisor to plan their course schedule and ensure they meet the major requirements. The Linguistics major is designed to be flexible, allowing students to pursue a range of interests and career goals.
